child.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
child.pub-comments: This language is referred to by Pawley as a “central Outlier” (see public comment of the Central Outliers node), but he makes no further mention of it as part of the Central Outliers subgroup. So, it may be a member of Central Outliers, but data at the time of publication was limited. “Data for NRA [Nukuria] and NMU [Nukumanu] are not available, but other observers have noted that there are very similar to TAK [Takuu], possibly dialect of the same language (see footnote 4)” (Pawley 1967:285).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
child.pub-comments: In Pawley 1966, this language was considered “unclassifed“ by the author, because “in most cases the descriptive data are not detailed enough to permit full comparative treatment” and that “there are indications of borrowing of uncertain extent from several as yet undefined PN [Polynesian] and non-Polynesian sources” (Pawley 1966:41). But in 1967, Pawley reclassified it as “Samoic-Outlier”. This tree represents the 1967 classification.
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1966. Polynesian Languages: A Subgrouping Based on Shared Innovations in Morphology, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 1 edn., vol. 75, 39-64. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society. , Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

But in 1967, Pawley reclassified it as “Samoic-Outlier”. This tree represents the 1967 classification.

child.pub-comments: “It seems likely that this subgroup will be confirmed when fuller lexical data appear for WFU [Futuna-Aniwa] and FIL [Mele-Fila]” (Pawley 1967:289).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.pub-comments: “Four Outliers (MAE [Mae], WFU [Futuna-Aniwa], WUV [West Uvea], and FIL [Mele-Fila]) are found in te New Hebrides” (Pawley 1967:282).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
child.pub-comments: “The central Outliers, TIK [Tikopia], SIK [Sikaiana], LUA [Luangiua], TAK [Takuu], NRA [Nukuria], NMU [Nukumanu], PIL [Pileni], and TAU [Taumako] form a second fairly closely-spaced chain” (Pawley 1967:282).
child.geography: far to the west of the Triangle languages
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
child.pub-comments: According to Pawley, published data for Anuta are nil or almost nil, therefore little is known about the language (1967:260).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
child.pub-comments: This language is referred to by Pawley as a “central Outlier” (see public comment of the Central Outliers node), but he makes no further mention of it as part of the Central Outliers subgroup. So, it may be a member of Central Outliers, but data at the time of publication was limited. Also, in Pawley 1966, this language was considered “unclassifed“ by the author, because “in most cases the descriptive data are not detailed enough to permit full comparative treatment” and that “there are indications of borrowing of uncertain extent from several as yet undefined PN [Polynesian] and non-Polynesian sources” (Pawley 1966:41). But in 1967, Pawley reclassified it as “Samoic-Outlier”. This tree represents the 1967 classification. Also, Taumako appears to be closely related to Pileni, and they possibly could be dialects of the same language (Pawley 1967:260-261).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
child.pub-comments: This language is referred to by Pawley as a “central Outlier” (see public comment of the Central Outliers node), but he makes no further mention of it as part of the Central Outliers subgroup. So, it may be a member of Central Outliers, but data at the time of publication was limited. Also, in Pawley 1966, this language was considered “unclassifed“ by the author, because “in most cases the descriptive data are not detailed enough to permit full comparative treatment” and that “there are indications of borrowing of uncertain extent from several as yet undefined PN [Polynesian] and non-Polynesian sources” (Pawley 1966:41). But in 1967, Pawley reclassified it as “Samoic-Outlier”. This tree represents the 1967 classification. Also, Pileni appears to be closely related to Taumako, and they possibly could be dialects of the same language (Pawley 1967:260-261).

child.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
child.pub-comments: “There is no substantial evidence at present connecting REN [Rennell-Bellona] with any other SO [Samoic-Outlier] language” (Pawley 1967:290).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
child.pub-comments: “...modern EUV [East Uvean] is the result of mixing two different speech traditions, one SO [Samoic-Outlier] and one Tongic. In view of this, perhaps modern EUV cannot be meaningfully assigned to any genetic subgroup of PN [Polynesian]. […] However, the following arguments are put forward briefly in support of the view that EUV is basically a SO language, overlain with recent borrowing from Tongic” (Pawley 1967:291). “The similarities of EUV are not to any particular SO language, but suggest more or less equal relationship to all other members of the SO group” (Pawley 1967:292).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1966. Polynesian Languages: A Subgrouping Based on Shared Innovations in Morphology, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 1 edn., vol. 75, 39-64. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society. , Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
child.pub-comments: In Pawley 1967, his “Proto-Samoic” has been combined with the previously unclassified Polynesian Outliers, hence the subgroup “Proto-Samoic-Outlier”.
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1966. Polynesian Languages: A Subgrouping Based on Shared Innovations in Morphology, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 1 edn., vol. 75, 39-64. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society. , Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
child.pub-comments: In Pawley 1966, Easter Island is “not sub-classified beyond its inclusion in NP [Nuclear Polynesian], partly because descriptive material for EAS [Easter Island] was not available for checking during the later stages of preparation of this paper. Elbert includes EAS in his Eastern Polynesian” (1966:41). However, in Pawley's 1967 paper, he also includes Easter Island in the Eastern Polynesian subgroup, and this tree reflects that decision. Pawley also quotes Elbert 1953 and Green 1966 that Easter Island may be “the sole member of a subgroup coordinate with the remaining EP [Eastern Polynesian] languages” (Pawley 1967:261), but he makes no further mention of it beyond this.
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1966. Polynesian Languages: A Subgrouping Based on Shared Innovations in Morphology, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 1 edn., vol. 75, 39-64. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society. , Pawley, Andrew K. 1967. The Relationships of Polynesian Outlier Languages, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 3 edn., vol. 76, 259-296. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.

child.pub-comments: In Pawley 1966, this language is just referred to as “Marquesan” (1966:41). The division of these languages is from Pawley 1967.

root.tree-val: Proto-Polynesian, a subtree of Austronesian: Pawley 1966, 1967
root.geography: spoken in the Polynesian Triangle, i.e. the apices being Hawaii in the north, New Zealand in the south, and Easter Island to the east; distributed across the Pacific from 155º E. to 109º W. longitude, and from 22º N. to 48º S. latitude; and the outlying areas of the “Triangle”
root.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 1966. Polynesian Languages: A Subgrouping Based on Shared Innovations in Morphology, The Journal of the Polynesian Society, no. 1 edn., vol. 75, 39-64. University of Auckland: The Polynesian Society.
